title: 2012–13 Pro12
text:
The 2012–13 Pro12 League (also known as the "RaboDirect Pro12" for sponsorship reasons) was the 12th season of the <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> competition originally known as the <a href="Pro14">Celtic League</a>, the third with its current 12-team format, and the second with <a href="RaboDirect">RaboDirect</a> as title sponsor.
<a href="Ospreys%20%28rugby%20union%29">Ospreys</a> were the defending champions, but they failed to qualify for the end-of-season playoffs.
The twelve teams that competed were the four Irish teams, <a href="Munster%20Rugby">Munster</a>, <a href="Leinster%20Rugby">Leinster</a>, <a href="Connacht%20Rugby">Connacht</a> and <a href="Ulster%20Rugby">Ulster</a>; two Scottish teams, <a href="Edinburgh%20Rugby">Edinburgh</a> and <a href="Glasgow%20Warriors">Glasgow Warriors</a>; four Welsh teams, <a href="Cardiff%20Blues">Cardiff Blues</a>, <a href="Dragons%20%28rugby%20union%29">Newport Gwent Dragons</a>, <a href="Ospreys%20%28rugby%20union%29">Ospreys</a> and <a href="Scarlets">Scarlets</a>; and two Italian teams, <a href="Benetton%20Rugby">Benetton Treviso</a> and newly created <a href="Zebre">Zebre</a>.
The title was won by <a href="Leinster%20Rugby">Leinster</a>, defeating <a href="Ulster%20Rugby">Ulster</a> 24–18 in the final.
Changes for the season.
Italy.
<a href="Zebre">Zebre</a> replaced <a href="Aironi">Aironi Rugby</a> after they had their licence revoked by the <a href="Italian%20Rugby%20Federation">Italian Rugby Federation</a> for financial reasons. Roberto Manghi will become their Head coach for their début season.
Scotland.
Ahead of this season <a href="Glasgow%20Warriors">Glasgow Warriors</a> moved home, leaving their previous home of <a href="Firhill%20Stadium">Firhill</a> in the <a href="Maryhill">Maryhill</a> area of the city for the smaller <a href="Scotstoun%20Stadium">Scotstoun Stadium</a>. They also came into the season with a new head coach, with former <a href="Scotland%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland</a> stand-off <a href="Gregor%20Townsend">Gregor Townsend</a> replacing <a href="Sean%20Lineen">Sean Lineen</a>.
Ireland.
<a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a>er <a href="Rob%20Penney">Rob Penney</a> replaced <a href="Tony%20McGahan">Tony McGahan</a> as director of rugby at <a href="Munster%20Rugby">Munster</a>, and fellow New Zealander <a href="Mark%20Anscombe">Mark Anscombe</a> replaced <a href="Brian%20McLaughlin%20%28rugby%29">Brian McLaughlin</a> as head coach of <a href="Ulster%20Rugby">Ulster</a>.
In Munster, <a href="Paul%20O%27Connell">Paul O'Connell</a> stood down as captain, with <a href="Doug%20Howlett">Doug Howlett</a> announced as his replacement.
Wales.
The Welsh regions saw a number of changes in coaching personnel, as <a href="Phil%20Davies">Phil Davies</a> took over the reins at <a href="Cardiff%20Blues">Cardiff Blues</a>, <a href="Steve%20Tandy">Steve Tandy</a> replaced <a href="Sean%20Holley">Sean Holley</a> as <a href="Ospreys%20%28rugby%20union%29">Ospreys</a> head coach and former <a href="Ireland%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Ireland</a> international <a href="Simon%20Easterby">Simon Easterby</a> succeeding <a href="Nigel%20Davies%20%28rugby%20player%29">Nigel Davies</a> at the <a href="Scarlets">Scarlets</a>, after he departed to take over at <a href="English%20Premiership%20%28rugby%20union%29">English Premiership</a> side <a href="Gloucester%20Rugby">Gloucester</a>. Scarlets also announced that <a href="Rob%20McCusker">Rob McCusker</a> would replace <a href="Matthew%20Rees">Matthew Rees</a> as captain.
On 28 August 2012, the <a href="Welsh%20Rugby%20Union">Welsh Rugby Union</a> announced a new annual event which will feature all four regions playing in a doubleheader at <a href="Millennium%20Stadium">Millennium Stadium</a> (similar to the long-established <a href="London%20Double%20Header">London Double Header</a> in the <a href="English%20Premiership%20%28rugby%20union%29">English Premiership</a>). The first of these events took place on 30 March 2013, with an initial contract set to run for four years.
Fixtures.
All times are local.
Round 4 rescheduled match.
This match – originally scheduled to be held during Round 4, on 21 September 2012 – was postponed due to the death of Ulster player <a href="Nevin%20Spence">Nevin Spence</a> in a farming accident on 15 September.
Round 19 rescheduled match.
This match – originally scheduled to be held during Round 19, on 30 March 2013 – was postponed due to a waterlogged pitch.
Play-offs.
Semi-finals.
The semi-finals were played on the weekend of 10/11 May 2013; these followed a 1 v 4, 2 v 3 system with the games being played at the home ground of the higher placed teams.
Final.
The final was contested on Saturday, 25 May 2013, between the winners of the two semi-finals.
Leading scorers.
Note: Flags to the left of player names indicate national team as has been defined under <a href="International%20Rugby%20Board">IRB</a> eligibility rules, or primary nationality for players who have not yet earned international senior caps. Players may hold one or more non-IRB nationalities.
